bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, July 26, 1922

div1.p: Connor discusses the campaign against yellow fever in Mexico, which he plans to finish soon. He thanks Carter for the critique of his manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, July 26, 1922

YELLOW FEVER COUNCIL
Mexico City - July 26th 1922
HENRY R. CARTER, M. D.
JUAN GUITERAS, M. D.
HIDEYO NOGUCHI, M. D.
JOSEPH H. WHITE, M. D.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have delayed writing you before this partly
because I was quite busy in Tampico arranging for closing
the campaign in that place, and partly because I have been travel-
ing with Doctor White over the country for the past three
weeks.

I appreciate very much your generous remarks on
the article “Stegomyia Indices and Their Value”, and made
the corrections as you suggested, all of which were valid.

Your letter of July 1st with enclosure of copies
on “Zones of Occurrence of Yellow Fever” came to hand a
few days ago, the classifications as you have outlined
them are quite clear and will be very useful.

I am enclosing copy of “Notes of Yellow Fever
in Mexico” which I am reading at the second annual yellow
fever convention to be held in Mexico City August 1st to
3rd, inclusive. You need not return the copy, but I would
be glad when you find the time, to have your criticism of
same, but please understand that if this means any extra
work do not undertake it.

I have asked Dr. Rose for permission to visit
Page 2 - Dr. Carter
you in Washington in November or December and at that
time we could discuss these notes.

You will be interested to know that the campaign
here is progressing very satisfactorily, in fact, I might
say that Doctor White believes that yellow fever has been
eliminated from Mexico, and is so reporting to the Depar-
tamento de Salubridad Pública. It is his plan to cease
active operation on October first, but continuing super-
vision over the entire country until the end of the year.

During the recent visit to Guatemala instructions
were issued for the complete cesation of the work in that
country and Salvador on the 31st inst. and in Belize on
August 31st.

You will also be interested to know that the
house incidence in Belize is 3.4 percent and in Guatema-
la and Salvador, less than 5 percent and has been for
months.

If you will permit me to I would like to take
you to taks for under scoring the word “when” in the sen-
tence in which you ask when your History of Yellow Fever
will be forthcoming. It is the first time in our long
acquaintance that I have heard a word or intimation of
pessimism from you, and I suspect in this instance it is
due to the terrific heat which the papers state is now
prevailing in Washington. If you could only realize
how anxious the scientific world is for your History of
Page 3 - Dr. Carter.
Yellow Fever, you would never under score another word
relative to its issue.

This letter brings to you and yours most sin-
cere good wishes, in which Doctor White tells me that I
can add that he most heartily joins.
